pullRequest.bodyText:
Early draft, to be discussed:

should filter init params be initialized differently? (through ConfigurationService props for instance)
does the logic match what you originally had in mind?
should the response status be stored too?
is HttpServletResponse.SC_CONFLICT the response status we'd like to have while the request is in progress? What about the content (some RFCs do have specifications for the content in this case)

Thanks

nodes.bodyText: We should activate the filter for all methods except GET/HEAD/OPTIONS/TRACE, which are the "safe methods" per RFC 7231 §4.2.1, and PUT/DELETE which are the "idempotent methods" per RFC 7231 §4.2.2. So in practice it's mostly POST yes, but maybe we use the RFC list instead to be clean.
It's worth adding log.debug calls in all the places where we have some logic to allow debugging, see what I did in NuxeoCorsCsrfFilter
The store name should default to a more explicit idempotentrequest for instance
You should protect against NPEs here, for the service and the store. Filters may be called very early/late and independently of Nuxeo startup itself.
For the content stored/returned we should manipulate only bytes, not a string representation.
400 -> HttpServletResponse .SC_BAD_REQUEST
One of them, probably the content, could have no prefix at all. And for the other I would have used a suffix, to make listings/dumps easier to read.
Don't use a TTL when putting null
For in-progress it's better to use a special status value (negative?) instead of the content. This way the content is pure content and not mixed with other logic.
As mentioned you should use bytes, not string. So use getOutputStream here instead of getWriter.

In addition to the status we must also save/restore all headers (which will include cookies and values like content-type and content-length).
So the whole status key in the k/v store could contain some JSON with this info (+ the http status)
In addition to this base test we should test for content that is not representable as a string, and headers (content type, custom headers, cookies).
Good for an initial prototype, but in general we can't buffer in memory.

nodes.bodyText: You already have @since 11.5 on the class, no need for it on all constants
FYI for new code I'm trying to use the idiom long DEFAULT_TTL_SECONDS = Duration.ofDays(1).toSeconds() to be explicit. And make the ttl a long everywhere
This should mention request idempotency instead of request.controller (which is an implementation detail)
Do we plan on backporting? Otherwise Set.of() is simpler
Suggest shouldIgnore -> isIdempotentMethod

Add detail: No idempotent processing done: method is already idempotent (the request isn't really ignored)
I would actually log the method here and not in a separate line.
No idempotent processing done: no Idempotent-Key present
KeyValueService not present
Check store is not null otherwise log and skip idempotent processing.
You have many if (...) { chain.doFilter(request, response); return; } so maybe let the caller do the chain call if this method returns a boolean false.

nodes.bodyText: You must also override the other write(byte b[]) and write(byte b[], int off, int len) methods from the base OutputStream otherwise performance will be horrible.
Maybe put new CopyingServletOutputStream(getResponse().getOutputStream(), capture) in a helper method as it's used twice.

It shouldn't be this method's responsibility to do the underlying close() as you can't guarantee it's going to be called in case of exceptions.
You should do a capture.flush() before reading the file.
Also you need to deal with tmp file deletion, maybe make CopyingResponseWrapper implement AutoCloseable and do the cleanup (underlying close + tmp file delete) in the close method. Then the filter can use a try-with-resources to make sure it's always closed.

Probably better to use getDuration here, it's more flexible for users. And rename the property to not have "seconds" in the name or value. Then DEFAULT_TTL_SECONDS can be just a duration too, and you only convert to seconds at the last moment: long ttl = getTTLSeconds() -> long ttl = getTTL().toSeconds().
You could have a single set with everything in it.
With log4j2 you should use {} in the log message, not string concatenation.
No need for NuxeoIdempotentFilter. in front of all your local constants.
Please do static imports of HttpServletResponse.SC_* constants
You should put the mapper in a static final field instead of constructing it every time.
I think stored.getHeaders().forEach(response::addHeader) will work as well.
You should do this first, and if there's an IOException (due to errors parsing the JSON) log it but abandon everything and process normally the chain.
Extend HttpFilter instead, which gives you doFilter methods overrides with parameters already converted to HttpServletRequest/HttpServletResponse.
We should have a protection here against captures that are too big, as the k/v store is not designed to store arbitrarily big payloads.
I'd like to see the response size in bytes logged as well, and the status (here and in the "return stored result" case)
Let's make this {"inprogress":true} so that it's at least valid JSON.
Could you add case with a multi-value header? For example Set-Cookie and Accept are common headers seen multiple times.
Any point making these protected?
Can it be null without getService throwing or an exception having been thrown before?
Same remark as above, can this happen?
Why don't we need chain.doFilter(request, wrapper); in this block?
Same remark: why don't we need chain.doFilter(request, wrapper); in this block?

Do we need to handle the edge case where the entry would expire between the previous call to store.getString(key + INFO_SUFFIX) and this call: store.get(key), in which case the latter would return null?

nodes.bodyText:
Can you call this copy instead? Same in CopyingServletOutputStream.
Also, detail, define that field last like in CopyingServletOutputStream. Or both first, but be consistent.
Could you add a comment: // invariant: only one of output or writer may be non-null, never both at the same time
I'd remove all the extra empty lines in these small methods.

Capture->copy here too.
As we probably don't want to materialize a huge byte array for nothing, let's also add a getCopySize method and check it first in the caller.

You have to set the header before sending the body, because in most cases (unless there's buffering, or in mocked classes) sending the body "commits" the response (see ServletResponse.isCommitted) and you can't set any header or status after that.
This should be wrapped with a if (!response.isCommitted())
You won't be able to set the header if the response is committed, which will usually be the case (unless buffering) after the flush. So maybe set before calling doFilter?
Constants -> all-uppercase
I don't like write much. Maybe save instead?
1d would probably be more readable.
